comment: The student provides a complete and rigorous proof. Although the method used (direct factorization and analysis of the greatest common divisor of the factors) is different from the inductive approach outlined in the rubric, it is a perfectly valid and powerful alternative. The argument is well-structured, showing that the odd parts of the factors are pairwise relatively prime and that a sufficient number of them are greater than 1 to guarantee at least n distinct odd prime factors. Combined with the prime factor 2, this correctly establishes the result. The solution is flawless.
